title: 2 Samuel Chapter 14 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Samuel chapter 14 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 14 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Samuel Chapter 14.

questions.question: Who perceived that the king's heart was toward Absalom?
options: Joab the son of Zeruiah
The woman of Tekoah
King David
Absalom
questions.correctAnswer: Joab the son of Zeruiah
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 14:1 says Joab the son of Zeruiah perceived that the king's heart was toward Absalom.

questions.question: What did Joab send to Tekoah to bring to the king?
options: A wise woman
A prophet
A soldier
A servant
questions.correctAnswer: A wise woman
questions.explanation: According to 2 Samuel 14:2, Joab sent to Tekoah and fetched a wise woman.

questions.question: How did Joab instruct the woman to appear when she came to the king?
options: As a mourner in mourning apparel
As a joyful messenger
As a soldier
As a prophetess
questions.correctAnswer: As a mourner in mourning apparel
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 14:2 describes Joab telling the woman to feign herself to be a mourner and put on mourning apparel.

questions.question: What relation did the two sons of the widow have to each other in the woman’s story?
options: They were brothers who fought
They were strangers
They were father and son
They were cousins
questions.correctAnswer: They were brothers who fought
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 14:6 says the two sons strove together, and one killed the other.

questions.question: What did the family of the slain son demand?
options: They demanded the slayer be delivered to them to be killed
They wanted peace between the brothers
They asked for forgiveness
They requested a fine
questions.correctAnswer: They demanded the slayer be delivered to them to be killed
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 14:7 states the family wanted the one who smote his brother delivered to be killed.

questions.question: What was the king's initial response to the woman’s plea?
options: Go to your house, and I will give charge concerning thee
He ignored her
He sent her away without speaking
He asked her to wait outside
questions.correctAnswer: Go to your house, and I will give charge concerning thee
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 14:8 says the king told the woman to go to her house and that he would give charge concerning her.

questions.question: What did the woman ask the king to remember?
options: The LORD thy God and not to suffer the revengers of blood to destroy more
His own power
The people of Jerusalem
The wise counsel of Joab
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD thy God and not to suffer the revengers of blood to destroy more
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 14:11 shows the woman asking the king to remember the LORD thy God that he would not allow the revengers of blood to destroy more.

questions.question: What comparison did the woman make about death in her speech to the king?
options: We are as water spilt on the ground, which cannot be gathered up again
We are like trees that grow tall
We are as stars in the sky
We are like mountains standing firm
questions.correctAnswer: We are as water spilt on the ground, which cannot be gathered up again
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 14:14, the woman compares death to water spilt on the ground, which cannot be gathered again.

questions.question: Who was responsible for putting the words in the mouth of the woman?
options: Joab
The king
Absalom
The prophet Nathan
questions.correctAnswer: Joab
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 14:19-20 reveal that Joab put the words in the mouth of the woman.

questions.question: What command did the king give to Joab after hearing the woman’s words?
options: Bring the young man Absalom again
Punish the widow
Send the woman away
Go to war
questions.correctAnswer: Bring the young man Absalom again
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 14:21 records the king telling Joab to bring Absalom back.

questions.question: How long did Absalom dwell in Jerusalem without seeing the king’s face?
options: Two full years
One year
Six months
Five years
questions.correctAnswer: Two full years
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 14:28 states Absalom dwelt two full years in Jerusalem and saw not the king's face.

questions.question: True or False: Absalom’s hair weighed two hundred shekels after the king's weight.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 14:26 says Absalom’s hair weighed two hundred shekels after the king’s weight.

questions.question: True or False: The king kissed Absalom when he came before him after his return.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 14:33 records that the king kissed Absalom when he bowed before him.

questions.question: True or False: Joab immediately went to Absalom when he was first sent for.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 14:29 shows that Joab did not come to Absalom when he sent for him the first and second time.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 2 Samuel 14:24: 'Let him turn to his own house, and let him not see my ______.'
options: face
kingdom
servants
people
questions.correctAnswer: face
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 14:24 states the king said Absalom should not see his face.

medium.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 14 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Samuel Chapter 14 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 14 teach us about the importance of wise counsel in resolving family conflicts?
options: Joab sent a wise woman to speak to the king to help bring reconciliation
Absalom immediately returned without any help
The king ignored the situation completely
The family was left to resolve their issues alone
questions.correctAnswer: Joab sent a wise woman to speak to the king to help bring reconciliation
questions.explanation: Joab recognized the king's heart toward Absalom and sent a wise woman to bring a message designed to soften the king's heart and encourage reconciliation (2 Samuel 14:1-3, 14:19-20, 14:21). This shows the value of wise counsel in resolving difficult family matters.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling to forgive a family member. According to 2 Samuel 14, what biblical truth would you share about forgiveness and restoration?
options: God devises ways to bring back the banished and restore relationships
It is better to hold grudges to protect yourself
Only the offender should seek forgiveness
Forgiveness is optional and not important for peace
questions.correctAnswer: God devises ways to bring back the banished and restore relationships
questions.explanation: The passage teaches that God does not disregard people but provides means for reconciliation and restoration of relationships, as seen in the plea that banished ones should not be expelled (2 Samuel 14:14, 14:21-23). This encourages believers to pursue forgiveness and restoration.

questions.question: How does the story of the wise woman teaching the king about justice and mercy challenge us to trust God’s guidance in leadership and decision-making?
options: The king is described as discerning good and bad like an angel of God
Leaders should rely only on their own wisdom without input
Justice should be ignored in favor of personal opinion
Mercy is not important in leadership
questions.correctAnswer: The king is described as discerning good and bad like an angel of God
questions.explanation: The woman praised the king for his wisdom to discern right from wrong, likening him to an angel of God, showing that God’s wisdom guides good leaders in making just and merciful decisions (2 Samuel 14:17, 14:20).

questions.question: In what way does Absalom’s experience teach us about humility and patience in seeking reconciliation with others?
options: Absalom returned to his house but did not immediately see the king’s face
He demanded immediate forgiveness without waiting
He refused to seek reconciliation
He took revenge without patience
questions.correctAnswer: Absalom returned to his house but did not immediately see the king’s face
questions.explanation: Absalom was allowed to return home but was not permitted to see the king’s face immediately, illustrating the need for humility and patience in restoring broken relationships (2 Samuel 14:24, 14:28).

questions.question: What lesson about faith and trust in God can be learned from the king’s promise to the widow that her son’s hair would not fall to the ground?
options: The king vowed, as the LORD lives, that not one hair of her son would fall
The king refused to make any promise
The widow was asked to solve the problem alone
The king ignored the widow’s plea
questions.correctAnswer: The king vowed, as the LORD lives, that not one hair of her son would fall
questions.explanation: The king made a solemn oath invoking the LORD’s name to assure protection over the widow’s son, encouraging trust in God’s justice and protection through human leaders (2 Samuel 14:11).

questions.question: How does the interaction between Absalom and Joab demonstrate the importance of honest communication in resolving misunderstandings?
options: Absalom honestly expressed his desire to see the king and asked Joab for help
Absalom ignored Joab completely
Joab refused to communicate with Absalom
Absalom set Joab’s field on fire without explanation
questions.correctAnswer: Absalom honestly expressed his desire to see the king and asked Joab for help
questions.explanation: Absalom sent for Joab twice to request that he help him see the king; when Joab didn’t come, Absalom’s servants burned Joab’s field to get his attention, showing the value of honest and persistent communication to resolve issues (2 Samuel 14:29-32).

questions.question: True or False: The chapter shows that God respects no person but has a plan to bring back those who are banished.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The woman of Tekoah states that God respects no person but devises means to not expel the banished, indicating God’s impartiality and care for restoration (2 Samuel 14:14).

questions.question: True or False: Absalom was immediately welcomed back to the king’s presence upon his return to Jerusalem.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Though Absalom returned to Jerusalem, the king instructed that he should turn to his own house and not see the king’s face at that time (2 Samuel 14:24, 14:28).

questions.question: How does the behavior of the wise woman in 2 Samuel 14 encourage believers in personal devotion and humility before God and leaders?
options: She put on mourning garments and humbly approached the king with a plea
She arrogantly demanded justice without respect
She avoided speaking to the king
She acted independently without any guidance
questions.correctAnswer: She put on mourning garments and humbly approached the king with a plea
questions.explanation: The woman was instructed to feign mourning and approach the king humbly, showing the importance of humility and reverence in prayer and petition (2 Samuel 14:2-4).

questions.question: Which biblical virtue is demonstrated by Joab when he seeks to reconcile Absalom with the king?
options: Perseverance and stewardship in seeking peace
Indifference toward family disputes
Selfish ambition
Ignoring reconciliation
questions.correctAnswer: Perseverance and stewardship in seeking peace
questions.explanation: Joab persevered by arranging for the wise woman to speak and later personally bringing Absalom back, showing stewardship of relationships and a commitment to peace (2 Samuel 14:1-3, 14:21, 14:23).

questions.question: When Absalom’s servants set Joab’s field on fire, what principle about resolving conflict can be learned from Joab’s response?
options: Joab addressed the issue directly by asking Absalom why it happened
Joab retaliated by destroying Absalom’s property
Joab ignored the incident completely
Joab reported Absalom to the king immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Joab addressed the issue directly by asking Absalom why it happened
questions.explanation: Joab came to Absalom and asked why his servants set the field on fire, demonstrating the importance of direct communication and seeking understanding in conflict situations (2 Samuel 14:30-31).

questions.question: How does the king’s final action toward Absalom illustrate the value of forgiveness and reconciliation in family life?
options: The king kissed Absalom, showing restored affection and forgiveness
The king banished Absalom permanently
The king ignored Absalom’s return
The king punished Absalom for his rebellion
questions.correctAnswer: The king kissed Absalom, showing restored affection and forgiveness
questions.explanation: After Absalom bowed before the king, the king kissed him, marking a public act of forgiveness and restored relationship (2 Samuel 14:33).

questions.question: A believer is feeling discouraged because of estrangement from family. Based on 2 Samuel 14, what can you share about God’s heart and practical steps toward restoration?
options: God supports restoration and can work through wise counsel and humility
Estrangement means God has rejected the relationship
Restoration is impossible once broken
Avoid all contact with estranged family
questions.correctAnswer: God supports restoration and can work through wise counsel and humility
questions.explanation: The chapter shows God’s provision for restoration through the wise woman’s counsel and the king’s mercy, emphasizing humility and seeking peace as steps toward reconciliation (2 Samuel 14:3, 14:14, 14:21).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Absalom was praised for his ________ from the sole of his foot to the crown of his head, with no blemish.
options: beauty
strength
wisdom
wealth
questions.correctAnswer: beauty
questions.explanation: Verse 25 states that no one in Israel was praised as much for his beauty from head to foot as Absalom was, highlighting physical perfection though not necessarily spiritual character (2 Samuel 14:25).

questions.question: What does the king’s command to not allow anyone to touch the widow after she appealed to him teach about the role of leadership in protecting the vulnerable?
options: Leaders have a responsibility to protect and uphold justice for the vulnerable
Leaders should ignore pleas for help
The vulnerable should fend for themselves
Justice is not a leader’s concern
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders have a responsibility to protect and uphold justice for the vulnerable
questions.explanation: The king instructed that anyone who harmed the widow should be brought to him and not allowed to touch her again, showing the biblical principle of leadership protecting those in need (2 Samuel 14:10).

hard.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 14 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Samuel Chapter 14.

questions.question: What role does Joab play in the reconciliation between King David and Absalom as seen in 2 Samuel 14?
options: He orchestrates a plan using a wise woman to persuade the king
He directly confronts Absalom and forces him to return
He advises the king to ignore Absalom's requests
He leads a military campaign to bring Absalom back
questions.correctAnswer: He orchestrates a plan using a wise woman to persuade the king
questions.explanation: Joab sends a wise woman from Tekoah to present a parable to the king to soften his heart toward Absalom (2 Samuel 14:1-3).

questions.question: The wise woman's parable in 2 Samuel 14:6-7 symbolically represents which biblical theme?
options: The danger of family feuds and the need for mercy
The importance of agricultural laws in Israel
The role of kings as military leaders
The consequences of idolatry
questions.correctAnswer: The danger of family feuds and the need for mercy
questions.explanation: The parable about two brothers and the threat of destroying the heir highlights the destructive nature of family strife and the need for clemency (2 Samuel 14:6-7).

questions.question: How does the king respond to the wise woman's plea regarding the revengers of blood?
options: He promises that not one hair of her son shall fall to the earth
He orders immediate execution of the avenger
He ignores her plea
He asks Joab for advice
questions.correctAnswer: He promises that not one hair of her son shall fall to the earth
questions.explanation: King David assures the woman that her son will be protected from the avengers of blood (2 Samuel 14:11).

questions.question: What literary device is chiefly employed in the wise woman's speech to the king in 2 Samuel 14:13-14?
options: Allegory
Hyperbole
Chiasm
Paronomasia (wordplay)
questions.correctAnswer: Allegory
questions.explanation: The wise woman uses an allegorical story to indirectly address the king's attitude towards Absalom (2 Samuel 14:13-14).

questions.question: The phrase 'as water spilt on the ground, which cannot be gathered up again' in 2 Samuel 14:14 reflects what theological concept?
options: The inevitability of death and human frailty
The permanence of divine judgment
The cleansing power of baptism
The abundance of God's blessings
questions.correctAnswer: The inevitability of death and human frailty
questions.explanation: The metaphor emphasizes human mortality and the irreversible nature of death (2 Samuel 14:14).

questions.question: Which Old Testament theme is foreshadowed by the woman's request that the king recall his banished, as seen in 2 Samuel 14:13?
options: Restoration and forgiveness of the exiled
The establishment of the Davidic covenant
The conquest of the Promised Land
The building of the Temple
questions.correctAnswer: Restoration and forgiveness of the exiled
questions.explanation: The woman's plea mirrors themes of restoration and forgiveness found throughout the prophets, emphasizing God's mercy towards the banished (2 Samuel 14:13).

questions.question: How does Joab demonstrate humility and gratitude after the king agrees to bring Absalom back (2 Samuel 14:22)?
options: He falls on his face and thanks the king
He immediately leaves the court
He demands a reward from the king
He rebukes Absalom for his absence
questions.correctAnswer: He falls on his face and thanks the king
questions.explanation: Joab bows down to the ground and expresses gratitude, showing humility before the king (2 Samuel 14:22).

questions.question: What condition does the king impose on Absalom's return to Jerusalem (2 Samuel 14:24)?
options: He must not see the king's face
He must pay a tribute
He must lead the army
He must marry a royal princess
questions.correctAnswer: He must not see the king's face
questions.explanation: David allows Absalom to return but forbids him from seeing his face, indicating incomplete reconciliation (2 Samuel 14:24).

questions.question: Absalom's physical appearance is described in 2 Samuel 14:25-26. What is significant about his hair according to the text?
options: It weighed two hundred shekels when cut
It was white as snow
He never cut it
It was shaved as a sign of mourning
questions.correctAnswer: It weighed two hundred shekels when cut
questions.explanation: Absalom's hair was notably heavy, and when cut it weighed two hundred shekels by the king's weight (2 Samuel 14:26).

questions.question: What does Absalom do to Joab's field when Joab refuses to come to him (2 Samuel 14:30)?
options: He burns it down
He steals the crops
He sells it
He gives it to the king
questions.correctAnswer: He burns it down
questions.explanation: Absalom's servants set fire to Joab's barley field in retaliation for Joab's refusal to come to him (2 Samuel 14:30).

questions.question: How does Joab finally respond to Absalom after his field is burned (2 Samuel 14:31)?
options: He comes to Absalom's house and questions him
He retaliates by imprisoning Absalom
He ignores Absalom's actions
He reports Absalom to the king immediately
questions.correctAnswer: He comes to Absalom's house and questions him
questions.explanation: Joab visits Absalom and asks why his servants set Joab's field on fire (2 Samuel 14:31).

questions.question: What is Absalom's expressed desire to Joab regarding his status before the king (2 Samuel 14:32)?
options: To see the king's face and be reconciled
To be made commander of the army
To be appointed as a judge
To be sent back to Geshur
questions.correctAnswer: To see the king's face and be reconciled
questions.explanation: Absalom wants Joab to intercede so he can see the king's face and asks to be judged fairly (2 Samuel 14:32).

questions.question: What is the king's reaction when Absalom comes before him after Joab's intercession (2 Samuel 14:33)?
options: He kisses Absalom
He sends Absalom away angrily
He ignores Absalom
He orders Absalom's arrest
questions.correctAnswer: He kisses Absalom
questions.explanation: King David kisses Absalom, signifying restored favor and reconciliation (2 Samuel 14:33).

questions.question: True or False: The wise woman from Tekoah was aware that Joab was behind her speech to the king.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The woman admits that Joab instructed her on what to say to the king (2 Samuel 14:19).

questions.question: True or False: Absalom immediately received full restoration to the king's favor upon his return to Jerusalem.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Though Absalom was allowed to return, he was not permitted to see the king's face for two years (2 Samuel 14:24, 28).

theological.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 14 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Samuel Chapter 14 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What motivated Joab to send the wise woman from Tekoah to King David?
options: Because he perceived the king's heart was toward Absalom
Because he wanted to deceive the king
Because the king requested a wise woman to counsel him
Because the woman was a prophetess
questions.correctAnswer: Because he perceived the king's heart was toward Absalom
questions.explanation: Joab acted because he understood that King David's heart was inclined toward Absalom (2 Samuel 14:1). This shows Joab’s role as an intercessor and strategist, aligning with God's providence in human affairs (Proverbs 11:14; Romans 13:1; 1 Samuel 16:7; James 4:13-15).

questions.question: How did the wise woman instructed by Joab present herself to King David?
options: As a mourner wearing mourning apparel and anointed not with oil
As a joyful prophetess with a message from God
As a soldier seeking justice
As a messenger from Absalom
questions.correctAnswer: As a mourner wearing mourning apparel and anointed not with oil
questions.explanation: She was told to feign mourning, putting on mourning apparel and not anointing herself with oil, symbolizing deep grief (2 Samuel 14:2). This act was meant to elicit the king’s compassion, reflecting biblical motifs of mourning and repentance (Jeremiah 6:26; Matthew 5:4; Ecclesiastes 3:4; Luke 10:13).

questions.question: What was the woman's story about her two sons meant to illustrate?
options: The danger of blood vengeance and the need for mercy
A historical event in King David’s family
The futility of mourning for the dead
The justice of the king in punishing sinners
questions.correctAnswer: The danger of blood vengeance and the need for mercy
questions.explanation: The woman’s story about her sons highlighted the destructive consequences of revenge killing and the potential loss of inheritance, urging King David to show mercy (2 Samuel 14:6-7). This reflects biblical teachings on mercy, justice, and the value of life (Exodus 21:12-14; Proverbs 3:34; Matthew 5:7; Romans 12:19).

questions.question: What was King David’s initial response to the woman’s plea?
options: He promised protection and commanded no harm to come to her
He ignored her and dismissed the case
He summoned Joab immediately
He ordered the execution of the surviving son
questions.correctAnswer: He promised protection and commanded no harm to come to her
questions.explanation: David assured the woman that no one would harm her and instructed that anyone who did should be brought to him (2 Samuel 14:8,10). This demonstrates God’s justice mediated through the king and the importance of protecting the vulnerable (Psalm 72:12-14; Isaiah 1:17; Proverbs 31:8-9; Luke 4:18).

questions.question: How does the woman describe God's attitude towards banished individuals?
options: God devises means so his banished are not expelled from him
God completely rejects and forgets the banished
God punishes banished individuals without mercy
God is indifferent to the fate of banished people
questions.correctAnswer: God devises means so his banished are not expelled from him
questions.explanation: The woman states that although death is inevitable and God does not respect persons, He still provides ways to restore the banished (2 Samuel 14:14). This aligns with biblical themes of divine mercy, restoration, and covenant faithfulness (Isaiah 43:25; Psalm 103:8-12; Luke 15:11-32; 2 Corinthians 5:18).

questions.question: What attribute of King David is praised by the woman in her speech?
options: His wisdom to discern good and bad, like an angel of God
His physical strength and valor
His wealth and political power
His strictness and severity
questions.correctAnswer: His wisdom to discern good and bad, like an angel of God
questions.explanation: She compares David’s wisdom to that of an angel of God, acknowledging his ability to judge rightly (2 Samuel 14:17). This reflects the biblical ideal of godly wisdom as a gift from God for righteous leadership (Proverbs 2:6; James 1:5; Daniel 5:14; Acts 6:10).

questions.question: Who was behind the woman’s story and the plan to bring Absalom back to Jerusalem?
options: Joab, David's military commander
Absalom himself
The prophet Nathan
The priests in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Joab, David's military commander
questions.explanation: The woman admitted that Joab instructed her and gave her the words to speak (2 Samuel 14:19-20). Joab’s role as a mediator and strategist fits the biblical pattern of God using human agents to accomplish His purposes (Exodus 18:13-27; 1 Samuel 25:32-33; Proverbs 11:14; Acts 9:15).

questions.question: What was King David’s command after hearing the woman’s plea and Joab's involvement?
options: To bring Absalom back to Jerusalem
To punish Absalom for his rebellion
To exile Absalom permanently
To execute Joab for deceit
questions.correctAnswer: To bring Absalom back to Jerusalem
questions.explanation: David instructed Joab to bring Absalom back from exile (2 Samuel 14:21). This act demonstrates the king's mercy and willingness to restore his son, foreshadowing themes of repentance and reconciliation (Luke 15:20; 2 Corinthians 2:7; Romans 11:29; Psalm 103:8-12).

questions.question: After returning to Jerusalem, what condition did David impose on Absalom?
options: Let him return to his own house but not see the king’s face
Let him immediately resume royal duties
Banished him again from the city
Imprisoned him for two years
questions.correctAnswer: Let him return to his own house but not see the king’s face
questions.explanation: David allowed Absalom to live in his house but forbade him from seeing his face (2 Samuel 14:24). This reflects a partial restoration and the complexity of familial and royal relationships, highlighting themes of discipline and grace (Hebrews 12:6; Proverbs 3:11-12; 2 Samuel 12:14; Luke 15:11-24).

questions.question: What is said about Absalom’s physical appearance in this chapter?
options: He had no blemish from head to foot and was very beautiful
He was weak and sickly
He had a scar from battle
He was ordinary-looking
questions.correctAnswer: He had no blemish from head to foot and was very beautiful
questions.explanation: Absalom was noted for his exceptional beauty without any blemish (2 Samuel 14:25). This physical perfection may symbolize an ideal kingly figure, though ultimately human sin and failure are shown (Genesis 1:27; Song of Solomon 5:10; Ezekiel 16:14; 1 Peter 3:3-4).

questions.question: What did Absalom do when he was frustrated that Joab would not send him to see the king?
options: He had Joab’s barley field set on fire
He went to the king himself
He fled to another country
He prayed to the Lord for patience
questions.correctAnswer: He had Joab’s barley field set on fire
questions.explanation: In anger, Absalom’s servants set fire to Joab’s barley field to provoke a response (2 Samuel 14:30). This shows human impatience and the consequences of strained relationships, illustrating biblical warnings about anger and revenge (Ephesians 4:26; Proverbs 15:1; James 1:19-20; Ecclesiastes 7:9).

questions.question: What was Absalom’s request when he finally spoke with Joab about seeing the king?
options: He wanted Joab to ask the king why he was kept from seeing him
He demanded to see the king immediately
He asked Joab to rebel against the king
He requested a permanent exile
questions.correctAnswer: He wanted Joab to ask the king why he was kept from seeing him
questions.explanation: Absalom asked Joab to inquire of the king why he was not allowed to see him and expressed willingness to accept death if guilty (2 Samuel 14:32). This reflects themes of repentance, justice, and the desire for reconciliation (Psalm 51:1-4; Isaiah 1:18; Luke 15:18-20; Hebrews 12:11).

questions.question: How did King David respond when Absalom finally came before him?
options: He kissed Absalom, showing forgiveness and restoration
He ordered Absalom’s arrest
He ignored him completely
He sent him away immediately
questions.correctAnswer: He kissed Absalom, showing forgiveness and restoration
questions.explanation: David kissed Absalom upon his return, symbolizing full reconciliation and fatherly love (2 Samuel 14:33). This echoes biblical themes of forgiveness and restoration, exemplified in the Prodigal Son parable (Luke 15:20; 2 Chronicles 30:9; Hosea 11:4; Psalm 103:12).

questions.question: What theological theme is emphasized by the woman’s speech about God not respecting persons but devising means for restoration?
options: God’s impartial justice combined with merciful provision
God’s harsh judgment without exception
God’s favoritism towards the righteous only
God’s indifference to human affairs
questions.correctAnswer: God’s impartial justice combined with merciful provision
questions.explanation: The woman highlights that God judges impartially but also seeks to restore the banished, showing a balance of justice and mercy (2 Samuel 14:14). This reflects the biblical doctrine of God’s righteousness and grace (Deuteronomy 10:17; Romans 2:11; Psalm 86:15; Micah 7:18).

questions.question: How does this chapter illustrate the role of human agency in God’s providence?
options: Joab’s strategic intervention leading to Absalom’s return
Absalom’s rebellion and punishment
The king’s immediate forgiveness without mediation
The prophet Nathan’s direct involvement
questions.correctAnswer: Joab’s strategic intervention leading to Absalom’s return
questions.explanation: Joab’s plan using the wise woman shows how God uses human agents to fulfill His purposes (2 Samuel 14:1-20). This aligns with scripture teaching that God works through human decisions and actions (Exodus 3:10-12; Esther 4:14; Romans 8:28; Proverbs 16:9).

questions.question: What does the interaction between David, Joab, and Absalom teach about restoration and repentance?
options: Restoration requires mediation and sincere repentance
Restoration is automatic without any prerequisites
Restoration depends solely on political power
Restoration excludes those who have sinned
questions.correctAnswer: Restoration requires mediation and sincere repentance
questions.explanation: Absalom’s return is mediated by Joab and conditioned by David’s willingness to forgive, illustrating that restoration involves repentance and intercession (2 Samuel 14:21-33). This is consistent with biblical teaching on reconciliation (2 Corinthians 5:18-20; Luke 15:7; Isaiah 55:7; James 5:16).

questions.question: What messianic theme can be discerned in David’s role as a merciful king in this chapter?
options: David as a foreshadowing of Christ’s mercy and reconciliation
David as a judge who condemns without mercy
David as a distant and unapproachable ruler
David as a military conqueror only
questions.correctAnswer: David as a foreshadowing of Christ’s mercy and reconciliation
questions.explanation: David’s merciful actions toward Absalom prefigure Christ’s role as the merciful King who reconciles sinners to God (2 Samuel 14:21-33). This is supported by New Testament references to Davidic kingship fulfilled in Christ (Isaiah 9:6-7; Luke 1:32-33; Romans 5:10; Ephesians 2:14-18).
